<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/61  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[855, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 514, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the stretching of a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 334, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows the set-up.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 128, 761, 389]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 402, 532, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 434, 144, 452]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 434, 920, 482]]<|/det|>
The student measures, and records in Table 1.1, the unstretched length \(l_0\) of the spring. He does **not** include the loops at the ends of the spring in the measurement. The value \(l_0\) is the length of the spring when the load \(L\) on the spring is \(0.00 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 495, 920, 529]]<|/det|>
Describe **one** technique you would use to obtain an accurate value for \(l_0\). Draw a diagram to illustrate your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 713, 920, 732]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 744, 146, 763]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 744, 920, 778]]<|/det|>
The student suspends a load \(L = 1.00 \text{N}\) from the spring. He records the new length \(l\) of the spring in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 790, 920, 823]]<|/det|>
He calculates the extension \(e\) of the spring using the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\) and records the value of \(e\) in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 836, 853, 854]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the procedure using loads \(L = 2.00 \text{N}\), \(3.00 \text{N}\), \(4.00 \text{N}\) and \(5.00 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 852, 579, 870]]<|/det|>
The readings and results are recorded in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> Calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring using the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\) when \(L = 5.00 \text{N}\). Record this value of \(e\) in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 119, 541, 134]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 144, 717, 319]]<|/det|>
\(L/\mathrm {N}\)\(l/\mathrm {cm}\)\(e/\mathrm {cm}\)
0.002.10.0
1.006.03.9
2.0010.68.5
3.0014.912.8
4.0019.317.2
5.0023.7
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 322, 920, 339]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 352, 146, 371]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 853, 386]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(L / \mathrm{N}\) (y-axis) against \(e / \mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0, 0). Draw the best-fit line. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 395, 799, 816]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 823, 920, 841]]<|/det|> [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show all your working and indicate on the graph the values you use.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 147, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
<form>G = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 144, 197]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 544, 198]]<|/det|>
\(G\) is numerically equal to the spring constant \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 920, 243]]<|/det|>
Record the value of \(k\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment. Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 256, 920, 274]]<|/det|>
<form>k = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 288, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 504, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the resistance of a wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 376, 121]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows the circuit used.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 128, 819, 352]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 368, 532, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 399, 146, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 399, 561, 418]]<|/det|>
The student measures the current \(I\) in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 429, 697, 448]]<|/det|>
She places the sliding contact S at a distance \(d = 50.0 \text{cm}\) from B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 870, 479]]<|/det|>
She measures the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{50}\) across length \(d\) of the resistance wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 491, 510, 510]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.2 shows the ammeter and voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 183, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 523, 767, 542]]<|/det|>
Record the readings on the ammeter and voltmeter. Include the units.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 549, 856, 720]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 734, 534, 753]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 765, 918, 784]]<|/det|>
<form>I = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[536, 797, 920, 816]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{50} = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 813, 920, 831]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 554, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the image produced by a lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 334, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows the set-up.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 128, 799, 282]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 298, 534, 316]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 324, 662, 456]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 469, 534, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 501, 144, 519]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 501, 598, 520]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.2 shows the height \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) of the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 364, 551]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.2, measure \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 562, 920, 581]]<|/det|>
<form>\(h_{\mathrm{O}} =\) .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 594, 146, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 594, 920, 628]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 is drawn to scale. The actual distance \(u\) between the illuminated object and the lens is \(20.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 641, 181, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 641, 495, 660]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1, measure the distance x.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 672, 920, 690]]<|/det|>
<form>\(x =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 702, 181, 720]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 702, 564, 720]]<|/det|>
Calculate the scale ratio \(r\) using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 730, 526, 755]]<|/det|>
\[r = \frac{u}{x},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 765, 353, 782]]<|/det|>
where \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 795, 920, 813]]<|/det|>
<form>\(r =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 792, 89]]<|/det|>
The student moves the screen until a focused image is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 181, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 497, 121]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1, measure the distance \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 133, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
<form>y = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[908, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 164, 181, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Calculate the actual distance \(v\) between the lens and the screen using the equation \(v = ry\). Use your value for \(r\) from **(b)**(ii).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<form>v = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[910, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 146, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 626, 291]]<|/det|>
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 297, 546, 329]]<|/det|>
\[f = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 333, 870, 352]]<|/det|>
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this type of experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 425, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
<form>f = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 458, 144, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
In this type of experiment, it can be difficult to judge the screen position that produces the clearest image.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 698, 523]]<|/det|>
Suggest **two** precautions or techniques to overcome this difficulty.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 170, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 570, 918, 588]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 645, 920, 664]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 675, 144, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 870, 694]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.2 shows the shape of the illuminated object. The image of the object is enlarged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 705, 728, 724]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram to show the image that you would see on the screen.

<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 876, 920, 894]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 917, 104]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the bending of composite strips of wood when they are loaded at one end. The composite strips are made from identical layers of wood stuck together, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how much composite strips bend when they are loaded at one end. Fig. 4.2 shows the set-up the student uses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 819, 181]]<|/det|>
The student has a number of composite strips made with two or more layers of wood.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 191, 897, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 279, 532, 297]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[101, 305, 858, 490]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 504, 532, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 536, 223, 553]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 460, 584]]<|/det|>
· state the variable that you are testing

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 583, 549, 600]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus that you would use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 599, 504, 615]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 615, 495, 630]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 630, 920, 661]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 660, 616, 676]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use your readings to reach a conclusion.
